Award.AwardTitle: Women in Statistics and Data Science Conference
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project provides support for a two and a half day Women in Statistics and Data Science (WSDS) Conference, which takes place in October 20 to 22, 2016 in Charlotte, NC. The focus of this conference is to empower women statisticians, biostatisticians, and data scientists by exchanging ideas and presenting technical talks on important, modern and cutting-edge research, discussing how to establish fruitful multi-disciplinary collaborations, and showcasing the accomplishments of successful women professionals. In particular, an ultimate objective of this conference is to increase the proportion of successful women researchers who have the technical skills, capacity and inclination to take on the challenges of 'big-data' oriented research in twenty-first century.

The two and half-a-day conference (starting the afternoon of October 20th) has multiple parallel technical sessions providing participants with the opportunity to learn about novel approaches and innovations addressing the challenges of big data. The technical sessions are complemented by career development sessions for all stages of participants starting from graduate students to senior professors, leadership development sessions, and formal and informal mentoring sessions. The conference, through multiple invited technical sessions highlights the research of female rising stars, mid-career and senior researchers and provides the opportunity to establish new collaborations. In addition, the mentoring and networking sessions of academic, government and industry participants guide early-career women participants on a successful career trajectory.

Conference URL: http://www.amstat.org/meetings/wsds/2016/index.cfm

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided support for a two and a half day Women in Statistics and Data Science (WSDS) Conference which took place from October 20 to 22, 2016 in Charlotte, NC. This conference empowered women statisticians, biostatisticians, and data scientists by showcasing the accomplishments of successful women professionals, discussing how to establish fruitful multi-disciplinary collaborations, sharing information on how to elevate their status by successful negotiations, balance work-life and increase visibility of women in the field. This conference met the critical need for a venue to address issues women face in these fields and provided formal and informal opportunities for the exchange of research, networking and mentoring. Although the need to increase diversity and highlight the pathways to success remains, WSDS 2016 made strides in addressing these issues.

Significant outcomes of the conference include:

  • Multiple professional development sessions provided information regarding negotiation skills, gender neutral communication skills, conflict resolution skills, work-life balance skills, and leadership skills.
  • Multiple invited technical sessions highlighted the research of female rising stars, mid-career and senior researchers, and served to present exciting and challenging transdisciplinary research topics and provided opportunities to establish new collaborations.
  • Multiple mentoring and networking sessions of academic, government and industry participants guided early-career women participants on successful career trajectories.
  • A session devoted to funding opportunities at NSF/NIH and other federal and non-federal funding agencies made women researchers aware of the opportunities available to fund their research and established mechanisms for post conference follow up.

The impact of the conference was in part reflected in a special issue of the journal Chance. The articles in this special issue were based on conference presentations. A summary including pictures from the conference are avaiable in Amstat News.

The impact of the grant is best summarized by a statement provided by a conference participant. “Wonderful conference! I enjoyed the chance to really get to know other women in statistics. There was a good mixture of getting to know people and a good balance of topics (keynote "autobiographies", hands-on workshop on R graphics, technical talks, and professional development)."
